elements.content: Zr-based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been known for their excellent stability; however, due to the high connectivity of the Zr6 nodes, it is challenging to introduce flexibility into Zr-MOFs. Here we present a flexible Zr-MOF named NU-1400 comprising 4-connected Zr6 nodes and tetratopic linkers. It exhibits guest-dependent structural flexibility with up to 48% contraction in the unit cell volume as evidenced by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. The expanded or contracted conformations of NU-1400 showed drastically different reactivity toward the hydrolysis of a nerve agent simulant owing to the size-selective effect toward the reactant.
elements.clean_text: Zr-based metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been known for their excellent stability; however, due to the high connectivity of the Zr6 nodes, it is challenging to introduce flexibility into Zr-MOFs. Here we present a flexible Zr-MOF named NU-1400 comprising 4-connected Zr6 nodes and tetratopic linkers. It exhibits guest-dependent structural flexibility with up to 48% contraction in the unit cell volume as evidenced by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. The expanded or contracted conformations of NU-1400 showed drastically different reactivity toward the hydrolysis of a nerve agent simulant owing to the size-selective effect toward the reactant.

elements.content: Constructed from metal ions or clusters and organic ligands, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a family of highly porous crystalline materials with well-defined structures. With only a few examples reported, flexible MOFs are an emerging subclass of MOFs that feature structural changes in response to external stimuli (e.g., guest, temperature, and pressure) while retaining porosity and crystallinity. These characteristics of flexible MOFs make them highly attractive for applications such as gas separation, drug delivery, sensing, and catalysis.
elements.clean_text: Constructed from metal ions or clusters and organic ligands, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a family of highly porous crystalline materials with well-defined structures. With only a few examples reported, flexible MOFs are an emerging subclass of MOFs that feature structural changes in response to external stimuli (e.g., guest, temperature, and pressure) while retaining porosity and crystallinity. These characteristics of flexible MOFs make them highly attractive for applications such as gas separation, drug delivery, sensing, and catalysis.

elements.content: Thermal, chemical, and mechanical stability of flexible MOFs are also desirable characteristics for practical applications. MOFs based on Zr6 nodes stand out due to their superior thermal and chemical stability from the strong directional Zr–O bonds. However, the stability of Zr-MOFs typically comes at the price of flexibility, as the highly connected Zr6 nodes with multitopic carboxylate linkers reduce the degrees of freedom in the frameworks, rendering the MOFs rigid. Considering the highly connected Zr6 node as a rigid body, a straightforward way of introducing flexibility into Zr-MOFs is to incorporate ligands with long and bendable/rotatable backbones, as exemplified by the breathing behaviors of NU-1105, MFM-133, and NPF-300 with 8-connected Zr6 nodes and nonrigid tetracarboxylate linkers.
elements.clean_text: Thermal, chemical, and mechanical stability of flexible MOFs are also desirable characteristics for practical applications. MOFs based on Zr6 nodes stand out due to their superior thermal and chemical stability from the strong directional Zr-O bonds. However, the stability of Zr-MOFs typically comes at the price of flexibility, as the highly connected Zr6 nodes with multitopic carboxylate linkers reduce the degrees of freedom in the frameworks, rendering the MOFs rigid. Considering the highly connected Zr6 node as a rigid body, a straightforward way of introducing flexibility into Zr-MOFs is to incorporate ligands with long and bendable/rotatable backbones, as exemplified by the breathing behaviors of NU-1105, MFM-133, and NPF-300 with 8-connected Zr6 nodes and nonrigid tetracarboxylate linkers.

elements.content: Alternatively, we postulate that increasing the degrees of freedom by reducing the connectivity of the nodes will help to engender flexibility. Therefore, tuning the connectivity of the Zr6 node to be 12-, 10-, 8-, 6- or 4-connected () by ditopic, tritopic or tetratopic linkers, offers a powerful means to modulate the degree of freedom at the intersections between the nodes and linkers. For instance, the presence of four monodentate carboxylate groups in DUT-98, a MOF with 12 coordinated carboxylate groups from four tritopic linkers, relieves some of the restrictions on the connectivity and endows this MOF with structural flexibility. Given that not all MOFs with low node connectivity are flexible, other factors, such as the geometry of linkers and the resulting MOF topologies, may also contribute to the flexibility. Bearing these criteria in mind, we set out to synthesize MOFs with low connectivity nodes and rigid linkers to realize flexible frameworks.
elements.clean_text: Alternatively, we postulate that increasing the degrees of freedom by reducing the connectivity of the nodes will help to engender flexibility. Therefore, tuning the connectivity of the Zr6 node to be 12-, 10-, 8-, 6- or 4-connected () by ditopic, tritopic or tetratopic linkers, offers a powerful means to modulate the degree of freedom at the intersections between the nodes and linkers. For instance, the presence of four monodentate carboxylate groups in DUT-98, a MOF with 12 coordinated carboxylate groups from four tritopic linkers, relieves some of the restrictions on the connectivity and endows this MOF with structural flexibility. Given that not all MOFs with low node connectivity are flexible, other factors, such as the geometry of linkers and the resulting MOF topologies, may also contribute to the flexibility. Bearing these criteria in mind, we set out to synthesize MOFs with low connectivity nodes and rigid linkers to realize flexible frameworks.

Connectivity of Zr<sub>6</sub>-Based MOFs<xref ref-type="fn" rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

The connectivity refers to the number of carboxylate groups from linkers in the extended framework coordinated to the node.
elements.clean_text: 1  Connectivity of Zr6-Based MOFs      a The connectivity refers to the number of carboxylate groups from linkers in the extended framework coordinated to the node.

elements.content:
The connectivity refers to the number of carboxylate groups from linkers in the extended framework coordinated to the node.

Herein, we report a flexible Zr-MOF based on 4-connected Zr6 nodes and a tetratopic organic linker that exhibits guest- and temperature-dependent structural changes. This flexibility leads to drastically different catalytic activity toward the hydrolysis of a nerve agent simulant, which is attributed to the size-selective effect of the different conformations of the MOF.
elements.clean_text:
a The connectivity refers to the number of carboxylate groups from linkers in the extended framework coordinated to the node.  

Herein, we report a flexible Zr-MOF based on 4-connected Zr6 nodes and a tetratopic organic linker that exhibits guest- and temperature-dependent structural changes. This flexibility leads to drastically different catalytic activity toward the hydrolysis of a nerve agent simulant, which is attributed to the size-selective effect of the different conformations of the MOF.

elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of ZrOCl2·8H2O and [1,1′:4′,1″]­terphenyl-3,3″,5,5″-tetracarboxylic acid (TPTC) in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) using formic acid as the modulator gave rod-shape crystals (NU-1400) (). Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that NU-1400 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Imma space group (a = 25.238(3) Å, b = 26.867(3) Å, and c = 16.779(2) Å at 200 K) (). The 3-D structure consists of 4-connected Zr6 nodes and TPTC linkers in an lvt topology with diamond-shaped channels along the a axis (). The 4-connected Zr6 node resembles a distorted paddlewheel structure where each pair of the carboxylate groups are on two of the adjacent edges of the Zr6 octahedron (, center). The as-synthesized NU-1400 from DEF (NU-1400-AS-DEF) also has four formate groups on each Zr6 node, as confirmed by the 1H NMR spectrum of NU-1400 digested in a solution of NaOD/D2O (). The remaining coordination sphere of each Zr ion is further fulfilled by hydroxy/water groups, as evidenced by the O–H stretching at 3650 cm–1 in its diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectrum (DRIFTS) (). Upon solvent exchange with acetone and subsequent thermal activation (NU-1400-TA), the porosity of the material was evaluated by argon sorption measurement at 87 K, which showed type I adsorption isotherm (a). BET area and the total pore volume were calculated to be 560 m2/g and 0.23 cm3/g, respectively. Pore size distribution based on DFT analysis indicates pore diameters of 5 and 8 Å (b), in line with the pores along the b and c axes ().
elements.clean_text: Solvothermal reactions of ZrOCl2⋅8H2O and [1,1':4',1"]terphenyl-3,3",5,5"-tetracarboxylic acid (TPTC) in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) using formic acid as the modulator gave rod-shape crystals (NU-1400) (). Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that NU-1400 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Imma space group (a = 25.238(3) Å, b = 26.867(3) Å, and c = 16.779(2) Å at 200 K) (). The 3-D structure consists of 4-connected Zr6 nodes and TPTC linkers in an  lvt  topology with diamond-shaped channels along the a axis (). The 4-connected Zr6 node resembles a distorted paddlewheel structure where each pair of the carboxylate groups are on two of the adjacent edges of the Zr6 octahedron (, center). The as-synthesized NU-1400 from DEF (NU-1400-AS-DEF) also has four formate groups on each Zr6 node, as confirmed by the 1H NMR spectrum of NU-1400 digested in a solution of NaOD/D2O (). The remaining coordination sphere of each Zr ion is further fulfilled by hydroxy/water groups, as evidenced by the O-H stretching at 3650 cm-1 in its diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectrum (DRIFTS) (). Upon solvent exchange with acetone and subsequent thermal activation (NU-1400-TA), the porosity of the material was evaluated by argon sorption measurement at 87 K, which showed type I adsorption isotherm (a). BET area and the total pore volume were calculated to be 560 m2/g and 0.23 cm3/g, respectively. Pore size distribution based on DFT analysis indicates pore diameters of 5 and 8 Å (b), in line with the pores along the b and c axes ().

elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of NU-1400. (a) The construction of NU-1400. (b) The framework topology of the  lvt  net (C, gray; O, red; Zr, green).

elements.content: Structural characterization and stability of NU-1400. (a) Ar sorption profile of NU-1400-TA. (b) Pore size distribution of NU-1400-TA based on Ar-87 K isotherm adsorption branch using DFT model. (c) PXRD patterns of NU-1400-TA after immersing in 0.1 M HCl solution, 0.01 M NaOH solution, and 90 °C water for 24 h. (d) Experimental and simulated PXRD patterns of NU-1400-AS-DEF, NU-1400-SA, and NU-1400-TA.
elements.clean_text: 2  Structural characterization and stability of NU-1400. (a) Ar sorption profile of NU-1400-TA. (b) Pore size distribution of NU-1400-TA based on Ar-87 K isotherm adsorption branch using DFT model. (c) PXRD patterns of NU-1400-TA after immersing in 0.1 M HCl solution, 0.01 M NaOH solution, and 90 °C water for 24 h. (d) Experimental and simulated PXRD patterns of NU-1400-AS-DEF, NU-1400-SA, and NU-1400-TA.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) indicated that NU-1400 did not decompose until 450 °C under air (). The chemical stability of NU-1400-TA was tested by soaking in hot water and solutions of pH = 1 and pH = 12 for 24 h, where the crystallinity and porosity were maintained as evidenced by PXRD (c) and Ar sorption (). These results demonstrated that the thermal and chemical stability are not compromised by the low connectivity of the Zr6 nodes in NU-1400.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) indicated that NU-1400 did not decompose until 450 °C under air (). The chemical stability of NU-1400-TA was tested by soaking in hot water and solutions of pH = 1 and pH = 12 for 24 h, where the crystallinity and porosity were maintained as evidenced by PXRD (c) and Ar sorption (). These results demonstrated that the thermal and chemical stability are not compromised by the low connectivity of the Zr6 nodes in NU-1400.

elements.content: One notable feature in the PXRD pattern of bulk NU-1400-AS-DEF is the peak shift compared to the simulated pattern from single crystal data (d), indicative of guest-dependent structural changes. The more distinct shifts in NU-1400-TA prompted us to obtain a crystal structure of NU-1400 after supercritical CO2 activation (NU-1400-SA, a = 25.385(3) Å, b = 30.661(3) Å, and c = 8.2771(9) Å at 200 K; ; ), which matched well with the Le Bail fitting results of NU-1400-TA (). This entails a 51% decrease in the c axis and a 43% decrease in the unit cell volume as compared to NU-1400-AS-DEF, suggesting much narrower channels in the activated samples (). This is not surprising given the computational prediction by Smit that lvt net is inclined to be flexible and the resemblance of the structure of NU-1400 to a foldable wine rack with diamond-shaped channels along the a axis.
elements.clean_text: One notable feature in the PXRD pattern of bulk NU-1400-AS-DEF is the peak shift compared to the simulated pattern from single crystal data (d), indicative of guest-dependent structural changes. The more distinct shifts in NU-1400-TA prompted us to obtain a crystal structure of NU-1400 after supercritical CO2 activation (NU-1400-SA, a = 25.385(3) Å, b = 30.661(3) Å, and c = 8.2771(9) Å at 200 K; ; ), which matched well with the Le Bail fitting results of NU-1400-TA (). This entails a 51% decrease in the c axis and a 43% decrease in the unit cell volume as compared to NU-1400-AS-DEF, suggesting much narrower channels in the activated samples (). This is not surprising given the computational prediction by Smit that  lvt  net is inclined to be flexible and the resemblance of the structure of NU-1400 to a foldable wine rack with diamond-shaped channels along the a axis.

elements.content: Structural changes of NU-1400 in different solvents from single crystal X-ray diffraction data. (a) Structures of NU-1400-AS-DMF, NU-1400-AS-DEF, NU-1400-water, NU-1400-EtOH, and NU-1400-SA viewed along a axis. (b) Schematic representation of the changes of the diamond-shape channel. (c and d) Unit cell parameters and volume changes of NU-1400 in different solvents obtained from single-crystal structure (200 K).
elements.clean_text: 3  Structural changes of NU-1400 in different solvents from single crystal X-ray diffraction data. (a) Structures of NU-1400-AS-DMF, NU-1400-AS-DEF, NU-1400-water, NU-1400-EtOH, and NU-1400-SA viewed along a axis. (b) Schematic representation of the changes of the diamond-shape channel. (c and d) Unit cell parameters and volume changes of NU-1400 in different solvents obtained from single-crystal structure (200 K).

elements.content: The flexibility of NU-1400 was further probed by variable temperature (300, 250, and 200 K) single crystal X-ray diffraction studies using the same NU-1400-AS-DEF crystal. A contraction in the c axis of ∼0.51 Å is accompanied by an elongation in the b axis of ∼0.15 Å as the temperature decreases from 300 to 200 K, resulting in an overall unit cell volume shrinkage of 334 Å3 (). This is further confirmed in variable temperature PXRD measurements, where a continuous expansion along the c axis was observed as the temperature increases from 200 to 400 K ().
elements.clean_text: The flexibility of NU-1400 was further probed by variable temperature (300, 250, and 200 K) single crystal X-ray diffraction studies using the same NU-1400-AS-DEF crystal. A contraction in the c axis of ~0.51 Å is accompanied by an elongation in the b axis of ~0.15 Å as the temperature decreases from 300 to 200 K, resulting in an overall unit cell volume shrinkage of 334 Å3 (). This is further confirmed in variable temperature PXRD measurements, where a continuous expansion along the c axis was observed as the temperature increases from 200 to 400 K ().

elements.content: Given the differences between the PXRD pattern of NU-1400-AS-DEF and the simulated one from the single crystal data (d), we suspect the degree of solvation and the guest solvent molecules must also affect the flexibility of the MOF structure. To confirm our hypothesis, single crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected after soaking the single crystals of NU-1400-AS-DEF in water or ethanol (NU-1400-water and NU-1400-EtOH) (a; ). X-ray quality crystals of NU-1400-DMF were independently synthesized using DMF as the solvent, where the resulting framework exhibits an isomorphous structure (see SI). Structural analysis on these four samples indicates that there is a monotonic increase in the length of the b axis and decrease in the c axis in the order of DMF, DEF, water, and ethanol (b,3c). Commensurate with these changes is the acute angle of the diamond-shaped channels, decreasing from 71.8° in DMF to 47.1° in ethanol (d). The unit cell volume changes from 12401 Å3 in DMF to 9379 Å3 in ethanol, corresponding to a ∼32% decrease (d).
elements.clean_text: Given the differences between the PXRD pattern of NU-1400-AS-DEF and the simulated one from the single crystal data (d), we suspect the degree of solvation and the guest solvent molecules must also affect the flexibility of the MOF structure. To confirm our hypothesis, single crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected after soaking the single crystals of NU-1400-AS-DEF in water or ethanol (NU-1400-water and NU-1400-EtOH) (a; ). X-ray quality crystals of NU-1400-DMF were independently synthesized using DMF as the solvent, where the resulting framework exhibits an isomorphous structure (see SI). Structural analysis on these four samples indicates that there is a monotonic increase in the length of the b axis and decrease in the c axis in the order of DMF, DEF, water, and ethanol (b,3c). Commensurate with these changes is the acute angle of the diamond-shaped channels, decreasing from 71.8° in DMF to 47.1° in ethanol (d). The unit cell volume changes from 12401 Å3 in DMF to 9379 Å3 in ethanol, corresponding to a ~32% decrease (d).

elements.content: Theoretical predictions of the flexibility of MOFs are generally obtained by assuming both the linker and the node to be rigid bodies; therefore, flexible topologies must originate from the hinge-like motion of the joints between the two rigid components. The reduction in the connectivity of the node and topicity of the linker allows for higher degrees of freedom and thereby more flexibility in compatible topologies. Analysis of the structural details of NU-1400 in different forms revealed that the deformation of the diamond-shaped channels is correlated to the bending of the carboxylate groups out of the plane of the adjacent phenyl ring and the simultaneous twisting of the carboxylate oxygen atoms around the phenyl-carboxy C–C bond (a). This torsional angle increases as the pore contracts, indicating additional disruption of the conjugation between the carboxy group and the phenyl ring (b). The out-of-plane bending of the phenyl-carboxy bond, however, first decreases as the pore contracted from NU-1400-AS-DMF to NU-1400-water, but then increases as the pore further contracts when soaked in ethanol (b). A larger out-of-plane phenyl-carboxy bending angle would endow extra strain and be less energetically favorable owing to the rigidity of the TPDC linker. Therefore, we postulated that the less bent carboxy group in NU-1400-water indicates a stronger affinity of water to NU-1400, likely due to the unique polarity and hydrogen-bonding ability of water compared to other solvents tested in this study. Different from the classic paddlewheel structure, where the O–O axis of adjacent carboxylate groups are parallel to each other, there is a dihedral angle between the two adjacent carboxylate groups on the Zr6 node in NU-1400 (, center). As a result, the carboxylate groups in NU-1400 have to both bend and twist to accommodate the hinge-like motion.
elements.clean_text: Theoretical predictions of the flexibility of MOFs are generally obtained by assuming both the linker and the node to be rigid bodies; therefore, flexible topologies must originate from the hinge-like motion of the joints between the two rigid components. The reduction in the connectivity of the node and topicity of the linker allows for higher degrees of freedom and thereby more flexibility in compatible topologies. Analysis of the structural details of NU-1400 in different forms revealed that the deformation of the diamond-shaped channels is correlated to the bending of the carboxylate groups out of the plane of the adjacent phenyl ring and the simultaneous twisting of the carboxylate oxygen atoms around the phenyl-carboxy C-C bond (a). This torsional angle increases as the pore contracts, indicating additional disruption of the conjugation between the carboxy group and the phenyl ring (b). The out-of-plane bending of the phenyl-carboxy bond, however, first decreases as the pore contracted from NU-1400-AS-DMF to NU-1400-water, but then increases as the pore further contracts when soaked in ethanol (b). A larger out-of-plane phenyl-carboxy bending angle would endow extra strain and be less energetically favorable owing to the rigidity of the TPDC linker. Therefore, we postulated that the less bent carboxy group in NU-1400-water indicates a stronger affinity of water to NU-1400, likely due to the unique polarity and hydrogen-bonding ability of water compared to other solvents tested in this study. Different from the classic paddlewheel structure, where the O-O axis of adjacent carboxylate groups are parallel to each other, there is a dihedral angle between the two adjacent carboxylate groups on the Zr6 node in NU-1400 (, center). As a result, the carboxylate groups in NU-1400 have to both bend and twist to accommodate the hinge-like motion.

elements.content: Origin of flexibility in NU-1400. (a) Illustration of the main contributions to the pore deformation. (b) Details of phenyl-carboxy bending angle and twisting angle changes in NU-1400.
elements.clean_text: 4  Origin of flexibility in NU-1400. (a) Illustration of the main contributions to the pore deformation. (b) Details of phenyl-carboxy bending angle and twisting angle changes in NU-1400.

elements.content: Compared to the flexibility exhibited by NU-1400-AS-DEF in response to guest molecules and temperatures, NU-1400-TA was found to be more rigid. When immersed in different solvents at room temperature, NU-1400-TA maintains its contracted conformation showing little dependence on the solvent molecules (). Variable temperature PXRD patterns of NU-1400-TA collected from 200 to 400 K also show the structural rigidity under different temperatures (). However, the structure changes to an expanded conformation when heated in a mixture of DMF and formic acid (), demonstrating that flexibility can be recovered in NU-1400-TA. Nevertheless, the more energy demanding structural expansion process of NU-1400-TA offers a stable “closed pore” form of NU-1400 under ambient conditions in solutions.
elements.clean_text: Compared to the flexibility exhibited by NU-1400-AS-DEF in response to guest molecules and temperatures, NU-1400-TA was found to be more rigid. When immersed in different solvents at room temperature, NU-1400-TA maintains its contracted conformation showing little dependence on the solvent molecules (). Variable temperature PXRD patterns of NU-1400-TA collected from 200 to 400 K also show the structural rigidity under different temperatures (). However, the structure changes to an expanded conformation when heated in a mixture of DMF and formic acid (), demonstrating that flexibility can be recovered in NU-1400-TA. Nevertheless, the more energy demanding structural expansion process of NU-1400-TA offers a stable "closed pore" form of NU-1400 under ambient conditions in solutions.

elements.content: Owing to the Lewis acidity of Zr (IV), a number of Zr-MOFs have been employed as catalysts in the hydrolysis of organophosphorus ester bonds of nerve agents and simulants. We hypothesized that the variable pore sizes of different conformations of the flexible NU-1400 would make it promising for shape-selective catalysis. To test this hypothesis, dimethyl 4-nitrophenyl phosphate (DMNP) was chosen as a substrate because it has a size (7.4 Å × 5.0 Å of the smallest cross section) larger than the window size of NU-1400-TA (a,b). As a result, DMNP will have limited access to the pores of NU-1400-TA whereas a more expanded conformation can more readily accommodate it (). The catalytic activity of NU-1400-TA was evaluated with 6 mol % of the MOF as a catalyst, and the DMNP conversion was monitored by in situ 31P NMR measurements (). The hydrolysis conversion profile of NU-1400-TA is shown in c, and the half-life calculated based on the initial rate is about 80 min. In comparison, a more expanded form of NU-1400 showed higher catalytic activity with a half-life of only 3 min, demonstrating that different configurations of the framework influence the accessibility of DMNP to the Zr-node active sites.
elements.clean_text: Owing to the Lewis acidity of Zr (IV), a number of Zr-MOFs have been employed as catalysts in the hydrolysis of organophosphorus ester bonds of nerve agents and simulants. We hypothesized that the variable pore sizes of different conformations of the flexible NU-1400 would make it promising for shape-selective catalysis. To test this hypothesis, dimethyl 4-nitrophenyl phosphate (DMNP) was chosen as a substrate because it has a size (7.4 Å × 5.0 Å of the smallest cross section) larger than the window size of NU-1400-TA (a,b). As a result, DMNP will have limited access to the pores of NU-1400-TA whereas a more expanded conformation can more readily accommodate it (). The catalytic activity of NU-1400-TA was evaluated with 6 mol % of the MOF as a catalyst, and the DMNP conversion was monitored by in situ 31P NMR measurements (). The hydrolysis conversion profile of NU-1400-TA is shown in c, and the half-life calculated based on the initial rate is about 80 min. In comparison, a more expanded form of NU-1400 showed higher catalytic activity with a half-life of only 3 min, demonstrating that different configurations of the framework influence the accessibility of DMNP to the Zr-node active sites.

elements.content: Hydrolysis of DMNP. (a) Hydrolysis reaction of DMNP. (b) Molecular size of DMNP. (c) Hydrolysis profiles of DMNP with open-pore form and narrow-pore form NU-1400.
elements.clean_text: 5  Hydrolysis of DMNP. (a) Hydrolysis reaction of DMNP. (b) Molecular size of DMNP. (c) Hydrolysis profiles of DMNP with open-pore form and narrow-pore form NU-1400.

elements.content: In summary, a flexible Zr-MOF with 4-connected nodes has been reported, and the guest- and temperature-dependent structural dynamics have been studied by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. NU-1400 possesses one-dimensional diamond-shaped channels that exhibit variable opening configurations in a single-crystal to single-crystal fashion. Taking advantage of the structural flexibility, both contracted and expanded forms of NU-1400 were tested as the catalysts for the hydrolysis of a nerve-agent simulant, DMNP, illustrating the potential application as a Lewis acid catalyst with adjustable accessibility to the catalytic sites. The intriguingly responsive properties of NU-1400 toward different solvents make it a promising candidate for selective adsorption and separation of small molecules.
elements.clean_text: In summary, a flexible Zr-MOF with 4-connected nodes has been reported, and the guest- and temperature-dependent structural dynamics have been studied by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. NU-1400 possesses one-dimensional diamond-shaped channels that exhibit variable opening configurations in a single-crystal to single-crystal fashion. Taking advantage of the structural flexibility, both contracted and expanded forms of NU-1400 were tested as the catalysts for the hydrolysis of a nerve-agent simulant, DMNP, illustrating the potential application as a Lewis acid catalyst with adjustable accessibility to the catalytic sites. The intriguingly responsive properties of NU-1400 toward different solvents make it a promising candidate for selective adsorption and separation of small molecules.

During the preparation of this paper, a MOF with a similar structure was reported by Li et al. (Nat. Commun. 2018, 9, 1745). The authors stated that the structure “exhibits poor stability and suffers structural collapse upon thermal activation and shows almost no porosity”.

Y.Z. and X.Z. contributed equally.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

During the preparation of this paper, a MOF with a similar structure was reported by Li et al. (Nat. Commun. 2018, 9, 1745). The authors stated that the structure "exhibits poor stability and suffers structural collapse upon thermal activation and shows almost no porosity".

cln_elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of ZrOCl2·8H2O and [1,1′:4′,1″]­terphenyl-3,3″,5,5″-tetracarboxylic acid (TPTC) in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) using formic acid as the modulator gave rod-shape crystals (NU-1400) (). Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that NU-1400 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Imma space group (a = 25.238(3) Å, b = 26.867(3) Å, and c = 16.779(2) Å at 200 K) (). The 3-D structure consists of 4-connected Zr6 nodes and TPTC linkers in an lvt topology with diamond-shaped channels along the a axis (). The 4-connected Zr6 node resembles a distorted paddlewheel structure where each pair of the carboxylate groups are on two of the adjacent edges of the Zr6 octahedron (, center). The as-synthesized NU-1400 from DEF (NU-1400-AS-DEF) also has four formate groups on each Zr6 node, as confirmed by the 1H NMR spectrum of NU-1400 digested in a solution of NaOD/D2O (). The remaining coordination sphere of each Zr ion is further fulfilled by hydroxy/water groups, as evidenced by the O–H stretching at 3650 cm–1 in its diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectrum (DRIFTS) (). Upon solvent exchange with acetone and subsequent thermal activation (NU-1400-TA), the porosity of the material was evaluated by argon sorption measurement at 87 K, which showed type I adsorption isotherm (a). BET area and the total pore volume were calculated to be 560 m2/g and 0.23 cm3/g, respectively. Pore size distribution based on DFT analysis indicates pore diameters of 5 and 8 Å (b), in line with the pores along the b and c axes ().
cln_elements.clean_text: Solvothermal reactions of ZrOCl2⋅8H2O and [1,1':4',1"]terphenyl-3,3",5,5"-tetracarboxylic acid (TPTC) in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) using formic acid as the modulator gave rod-shape crystals (NU-1400) (). Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that NU-1400 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Imma space group (a = 25.238(3) Å, b = 26.867(3) Å, and c = 16.779(2) Å at 200 K) (). The 3-D structure consists of 4-connected Zr6 nodes and TPTC linkers in an  lvt  topology with diamond-shaped channels along the a axis (). The 4-connected Zr6 node resembles a distorted paddlewheel structure where each pair of the carboxylate groups are on two of the adjacent edges of the Zr6 octahedron (, center). The as-synthesized NU-1400 from DEF (NU-1400-AS-DEF) also has four formate groups on each Zr6 node, as confirmed by the 1H NMR spectrum of NU-1400 digested in a solution of NaOD/D2O (). The remaining coordination sphere of each Zr ion is further fulfilled by hydroxy/water groups, as evidenced by the O-H stretching at 3650 cm-1 in its diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectrum (DRIFTS) (). Upon solvent exchange with acetone and subsequent thermal activation (NU-1400-TA), the porosity of the material was evaluated by argon sorption measurement at 87 K, which showed type I adsorption isotherm (a). BET area and the total pore volume were calculated to be 560 m2/g and 0.23 cm3/g, respectively. Pore size distribution based on DFT analysis indicates pore diameters of 5 and 8 Å (b), in line with the pores along the b and c axes ().

cln_elements.content:
Connectivity of Zr<sub>6</sub>-Based MOFs<xref ref-type="fn" rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

The connectivity refers to the number of carboxylate groups from linkers in the extended framework coordinated to the node.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Connectivity of Zr6-Based MOFs      a The connectivity refers to the number of carboxylate groups from linkers in the extended framework coordinated to the node.

cln_elements.content: Structure of NU-1400. (a) The construction of NU-1400. (b) The framework topology of the lvt net (C, gray; O, red; Zr, green).

cln_elements.content: Structural characterization and stability of NU-1400. (a) Ar sorption profile of NU-1400-TA. (b) Pore size distribution of NU-1400-TA based on Ar-87 K isotherm adsorption branch using DFT model. (c) PXRD patterns of NU-1400-TA after immersing in 0.1 M HCl solution, 0.01 M NaOH solution, and 90 °C water for 24 h. (d) Experimental and simulated PXRD patterns of NU-1400-AS-DEF, NU-1400-SA, and NU-1400-TA.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Structural characterization and stability of NU-1400. (a) Ar sorption profile of NU-1400-TA. (b) Pore size distribution of NU-1400-TA based on Ar-87 K isotherm adsorption branch using DFT model. (c) PXRD patterns of NU-1400-TA after immersing in 0.1 M HCl solution, 0.01 M NaOH solution, and 90 °C water for 24 h. cln_elements.content: Structural changes of NU-1400 in different solvents from single crystal X-ray diffraction data. (a) Structures of NU-1400-AS-DMF, NU-1400-AS-DEF, NU-1400-water, NU-1400-EtOH, and NU-1400-SA viewed along a axis. (b) Schematic representation of the changes of the diamond-shape channel. (c and d) Unit cell parameters and volume changes of NU-1400 in different solvents obtained from single-crystal structure (200 K).

metadata.title:
A Flexible
Metal–Organic Framework with 4‑Connected
Zr6 Nodes
